Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: From 21 cm Observations to Precision Reionization Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this program is to study the epoch of reionization (EoR) through the redshifted hydrogen emission line at rest wavelength 21 cm. The EoR is one of the last unexplored phases in the history of the universe. Broader impacts of the work include training of women and underrepresented minority students through a program called Research Experiences for Non-Traditional Undergraduates (RENTU).

The award will provide support for the US-based imaging power spectrum analysis team, which has been at the forefront of analyzing data from the Mileura Widefield Array telescope in Australia, and will provide one of the cornerstone analysis pipelines for the new Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array (HERA), an NSF-supported radio telescope in South Africa.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The very early universe, when the first stars formed and collecting into galaxies is the last epoch to yield its secrets. Observations of this time period are needed to explain how, contrary to most simulations, stars formed from cosmological hydrogen and the origin of super-massive black holes, thought to be seeded during this time period? These and other questions are central to much deep observing by the worlds largest telescopes, however optical and infrared can only probe so far back before stars start to peter out. A new probe which is not so limited is the 21cm radio emission from the relic cosmological hydrogen. The depth of this line is extremely sensitive to sources of energy as well as the distribution of matter. In the past decade several arrays including the Murchison Widefield Array have been built to probe this emission which is redshifted to a wavelength of 2 to 4 meters. This new technique is not without challenges, requiring development of a new suite of analytical and instrumental approaches. The goal of the Precision Reionization Science project is to further develop techniques enabling 21 cm cosmological studies as a precision cosmological probe.  Study areas include building more precise foreground catalogs, predicting and measuring the effects of calibration errors, and producing new limits on the power spectrum. One major requirement underlying all areas is the need for accurate quality instrument simulation. The ASU goal is to develop an open source framework for simulating 21cm arrays at the highest possible precision and to connect the simulator to existing pipelines. Another goal was to develop techniques for finding and characterizing low level system defects which decrease instrument sensitivity. These studies led to a number of publications across the collaboration as well the development of two code-bases which are increasingly adopted by other researchers. These codes were developed with modern software engineering and community development practices which enables other researchers to use them.  

The project also supported the development of an increasingly diverse community of researchers.  An experience doing research in a lab is an important part of the process of becoming involved in science careers. However for the growing number of people taking different paths through higher education traditional research experiences are not a good fit.  As a part of this project, the team developed the Research Experiences for Non-traditional Undergraduates program which supports students with stipends and mentoring to have an REU-like experience at their home university. In the first two years, the project supported seven students, five who are under represented minorities, three women and one veteran. The RENTU program has grown, with more projects adding their support to increase the number of students and build strong yearly cohorts.  This new belonging propagates back through family, friends and forward through their children. The impact ripples through the community, giving many people a first direct connection to the research their society is doing.
